publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: ... im Übermaß [wtl. zuviel] genossen, trocknet [sie] die Kehle aus, bedrückt das Herz [und] macht [es] schlaff, ... macht allmählich den Stuhlgang kümmerlich, träge(?), hart [und] fest [und] ruft außer diesen noch weitere [wtl. dies usw.] Windkrankheiten hervor.

... consumed in excess [lit. too much], [it] dries up the throat, oppresses the heart [and] makes [it] limp, ..., gradually makes dejection poor, slow(?), hard [and] firm [and], apart from these, it causes other [lit. these, etc.] wind-illnesses.
Now I will recite the incompatibilities.
Whenever I recite the incompatibilities, this [is] to be understood.

Wann immer ich Unverträglichkeiten lehre, [ist] dies zu wissen: Auf diese Weise [d.h. Unverträgliches] gegessen habend, [ist] mit Vomieren zu behandeln [und] mit Purgieren zu behandeln. Wenn [dies] aber nicht gemacht wird, ruft [es] Wundrose, Wasserbauch [und] Ausschlag mit Pusteln hervor, oder es entstehen Fisteln, ...

Whenever I teach intolerances, this [is] to be known: having eaten in this way [i.e. something intolerable], [this] must be treated with vomiting [and must] be treated with laxation. If, however, [this] is not done, [it] will cause erysipelas, abdominal dropsy [and] a rash with pustules, or fistulas will develop, ...

But if one does not do [it], [this] causes erysipelas, hydropsy and praśśāṅkaṃ, or [he has] haemorrhoids, is blind, drugged, obstructed, or [he] even [has] diseases such as snaittu, leprosy, emaciation, fever, jaundice, cholera [or] insanity.
Now I will recite the power[s] of the medicines.

p.note: 42: "in almost perfect state of preservation. Written in medium ductus".

list.item: a1 olyapotstse|olyapotse māka śeśu ko(r) āsäṣṣäṃ • arañc nuskaṣṣäṃ|ñuskaṣṣäṃ staukkäṣṣäṃ • kantwa eṅkastär auloṃ prutkäṣṣäṃ • śukkär āsäṣṣäṃ • lau- a2 -kar kwaräṣ • raiweṃ sticce yamaṣṣäṃ śireṃ • prakreṃ tesa wärñai yenteṣṣana tekaṃma erṣäṃ || tusāksa ṣe śūke|śuke māka mā śwālle || a3 || ñake wirotänta weñau || läkṣi malkwermpa wirot swāñana mīsa|misa mitämpa wirot • klyemoṃ warne lwasāts misampa a4 mit panit wirot • malkwer patsaṃ uppāläṣṣana witsakaṃmpa kärkoṣ śātrempa mā śwālle • k_use śuwaṃ patko mä- a5 -sketär • tranto naitwe korne karkar yamaṣṣäṃ|yamaṣäṃ • patsaṃ śemesteṃ kwrarāk arkwañai śeśuwermeṃ mā malkwer yokalle • k_use yokäṃ a6 kaswātse mäsketär • ekṣinekäṃñana mīsa|misa akauwse • t· y· k· lāst tesa wärñai āmpäl śūke|śuke salyiṃ ṣpä malkwermpa b1 eweta || pippāl • kuñi-mot eṣe mā śwālle • aukṣu kuñi-mot mā śwālle • mit emalye warämpa mā yokalle • emallene yku- b2 -weṣepi mā yokalle • mit ṣalype ṣeme yärm mā śwālle • mit ylaiñeṣṣe warämpa ṣe mā yokalle • mitämpa uppāläṣṣana b3 tanāñ mā śwālle mit śeśuwermeṃ emalle war mā yokalle ente ente wirotänta weñau te kärsanalle || te-yäkne- b4 -sa śeśuwermeṃ aṅkaiṃ yāmtsisa yamaṣṣälle|yamaṣälle • tälpāllesa yamaṣṣälle|yamaṣle • kwri no mā yāmtär vaisarp • warkatsa • praśśā- b5 -ṅkaṃ erṣäṃ • epe bhagaṇḍālänta mäskenträ tärrek murc • taṅki snaittu ra • kāswo • świtär śoṣ tsärkalle kamāl wīcuṣik śa- b6 -le grahaṃ tesa wärñai tek(aṃma mäs)kenträ || || ñake saṃtkentas maiyya weñau || mit pit leś preñcaṃne śpālmeṃ • ṣalype

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a3 Now I will recite the incompatibilities. 656
b3 Whenever I recite the incompatibilities, this [is] to be understood. 378
b4-6 But if one does not do [it], [this] causes erysipelas, hydropsy and praśśāṅkaṃ, or [he has] haemorrhoids, is blind, drugged, obstructed, or [he] even [has] diseases such as snaittu, leprosy, emaciation, fever, jaundice, cholera [or] insanity. 675
b6 Now I will recite the power[s] of the medicines. 656


Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a1-2 ... im Übermaß [wtl. zuviel] genossen, trocknet [sie] die Kehle aus, bedrückt das Herz [und] macht [es] schlaff, ... macht allmählich den Stuhlgang kümmerlich, träge(?), hart [und] fest [und] ruft außer diesen noch weitere [wtl. dies usw.] Windkrankheiten hervor. 329
b3-5 Wann immer ich Unverträglichkeiten lehre, [ist] dies zu wissen: Auf diese Weise [d.h. Unverträgliches] gegessen habend, [ist] mit Vomieren zu behandeln [und] mit Purgieren zu behandeln. Wenn [dies] aber nicht gemacht wird, ruft [es] Wundrose, Wasserbauch [und] Ausschlag mit Pusteln hervor, oder es entstehen Fisteln, ... 230


[[Broomhead I]]: 43-44 translates:

a1 Eaten in excessive quantity [it] dries the throat [and] oppresses the heart causing it fatigue; [it] also affects the voice [and] contracts the arteries/blood-vessels [and] it dries the sperm. [affects the virility].

a2 [It] gradually makes the stools/faeces troubled, sluggish, hard [and] firm. [It] provokes this and similar wind ailments. Consequently [that which] has one and the same taste should not be eaten to excess.

a3 Now I shall teach the incompabilities. Fish with milk [is] incompability. Pork with honey [is] incompatible. Honey [and] molasses with the flesh of animals in standing water [is] incompatible.

a4 Milk [and saffron] pollen [is] not to be eaten with lotus roots [and] with corn bound (at the roots). Whosoever should eat [this] gets indigestion.

a5 causes cancer in the tratto, the temple and the throat. After having eaten saffron-pollen, kwarāk śemesteṃ and arkwañai one should not drink milk. Whosoever should drink [it]

a6 becomes leprous. Peacock (?) flesh akauwse ... lāst and similar substances with a bitter taste [and] salt [are also] at variance with milk.

b1 Long pepper is not to be eaten with rice-brandy [and] not to be eaten with matured rice-brandy. Honey is not to be drunk with warm water.

b2 One who has gone into a hot place should drink nothing. Honey and oil are not to be drunk in the same quantity. [And] honey is not to be drunk with dew (-water). With honey lotus

b3 grains are not to be eaten. Having eaten honey one should not drink hot water. Whenever I teach incompatabilities this is to be known.

b4 Once one has eaten in this way he should be made to vomit [and] one should use a purgative. But if one does not do this [then] [that] causes erysipelas, hydropsy and praśśāṅkaṃ

b5 or there are haemorrhoids, blind(ness), druggedness, obstructedness and even snaittu leprosy emaciation fever jaundice cholera [and] insanity.

b6 this and similar diseases [there] are. Now I shall teach the power of the remedies. Honey [is] among the best [remedies] for eliminating gall and phlegm. Oil ...

[[Broomhead I]]: 43, 44-45, 48 also contains further notes on the the text and the language.
[[Broomhead I]]: 42: "in almost perfect state of preservation. Written in medium ductus".

a1 olyapotse māka śeśu ko(–)\• [ā_s_aṣ]_ṣ_aṃ • arañcä\ ñuska_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ stauk_k_a_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ • kantwa eṅkas_t_a_r\• auloṃ pru_t_k_a_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ • śuk_k_a_r\• ā_s_a_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ • lau- a2 -ka_r\• kwa_r_a_ṣ\• • raiweṃ sticce yama_ṣ_ṣ_aṃ śireṃ • prakreṃ tesa wärñai yenteṣṣana tekaṃma er_ṣ_aṃ || tusāksa ṣe śuke māka mā śwālle || a3 || ñake wiro_t_anta weñau || _l_akṣi malkwermpa wiro_t\• swāñana misa mi_t_ampa wiro_t\• • klyemoṃ warne lwasāt_s\• misampa a4 mi_t\• pani_t\• wiro_t\• • malkwe_r\• patsaṃ uppā_l_aṣṣana witsakaṃmpa _k_arko_ṣ\ śātrempa mā śwālle • k_use śuwaṃ patko _m_a- a5 -ske_t_a_r\• • tranto naitwe korne karka_r\ yama_ṣ_aṃ • patsaṃ śemesteṃ kwrarā_k\• arkwañai śeśuwermeṃ mā malkwe_r\• yokalle • k_use yo_k_aṃ a6 kaswātse _m_aske_t_a_r\• • ekṣine_k_aṃñana misa akauwse • [t]· [y]· [k]· lās_tä\ tesa wärñai ām_p_a_l\ śuke salyiṃ _ṣ_p_a malkwermpa b1 eweta || pippā_l\• • kuñi-mo_t\• eṣe mā śwālle • aukṣu kuñ[i]-m[o]_t[\] m[ā] śwālle • mi_t\ emalye wa_r_ampa mā yokalle • emallene yku- b2 -weṣepi mā yokalle • mi_t\• ṣalype ṣeme yär_m\ mā śwālle • mi_t\ ylaiñeṣṣe wa_r_ampa ṣe mā yokalle • mi_t_ampa uppā_l_aṣṣana b3 tanāñä\ mā śwālle mi_t\• śeśuwermeṃ emalle wa_r\ mā yokalle ente ente wiro_t_anta weñau te _k_arsanalle || te-yäkne- b4 -sa śeśuwermeṃ aṅkaiṃ yāmtsisa yama_ṣ_alle • _t_alpāllesa yamaṣle • kwri no mā yām_t_a_r\ vaisar_p\ • warkatsa • praśśā- b5 -ṅkaṃ er_ṣ_aṃ • epe bhagaṇḍā_l_anta _m_askent_r_a _t_arre_k\• murcä\ • taṅki snaittu ra • kāswo • świ_t_a_r\• śo_ṣ\• tsärkalle kamā_l\• wīcuṣi_k\ śa- b6 -le grahaṃ tesa wärñai te[k]· [– –] ·k[e]nt_r_a || || ñake saṃtkenta_s\• maiyya weñau || mi_t\ pi_t\ le_ś\• preñcaṃne śpālmeṃ • ṣalype

div.p: <citedRange>43-44</citedRange></bibl> translates: </p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a1"/> Eaten in excessive quantity [it] dries the throat [and] oppresses the heart causing it fatigue; [it] also affects the voice [and] contracts the arteries/blood-vessels [and] it dries the sperm. [affects the virility].</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a2"/> [It] gradually makes the stools/faeces troubled, sluggish, hard [and] firm. [It] provokes this and similar wind ailments. Consequently [that which] has one and the same taste should not be eaten to excess.</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a3"/> Now I shall teach the incompabilities. Fish with milk [is] incompability. Pork with honey [is] incompatible. Honey [and] molasses with the flesh of animals in standing water [is] incompatible.</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a4"/> Milk [and saffron] pollen [is] not to be eaten with lotus roots [and] with corn bound (at the roots). Whosoever should eat [this] gets indigestion.</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a5"/> causes cancer in the tratto, the temple and the throat. After having eaten saffron-pollen, kwarāk śemesteṃ and arkwañai one should not drink milk. Whosoever should drink [it]</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__a6"/> becomes leprous. Peacock (?) flesh akauwse ... lāst and similar substances with a bitter taste [and] salt [are also] at variance with milk.</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b1"/> Long pepper is not to be eaten with rice-brandy [and] not to be eaten with matured rice-brandy. Honey is not to be drunk with warm water.</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b2"/> One who has gone into a hot place should drink nothing. Honey and oil are not to be drunk in the same quantity. [And] honey is not to be drunk with dew (-water). With honey lotus</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b3"/> grains are not to be eaten. Having eaten honey one should not drink hot water. Whenever I teach incompatabilities this is to be known.</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b4"/> Once one has eaten in this way he should be made to vomit [and] one should use a purgative. But if one does not do this [then] [that] causes erysipelas, hydropsy and praśśāṅkaṃ</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b5"/> or there are haemorrhoids, blind(ness), druggedness, obstructedness and even snaittu leprosy emaciation fever jaundice cholera [and] insanity.</p><p><ref type="ms" target="__b6"/> this and similar diseases [there] are. Now I shall teach the power of the remedies. Honey [is] among the best [remedies] for eliminating gall and phlegm. Oil ...</p><p><bibl><title corresp="ref:broomhead1962"/><citedRange>43, 44-45, 48</citedRange></bibl> also contains further notes on the the text and the language.</p></project_comment>
